title: Transgender Healthcare for ICE Detainees in Contracted Jail Facilities (Department of Homeland Security)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

For the period of January 1, 2023, through the date this request is processed, I request records concerning the provision of medical and mental health care to transgender individuals detained in facilities operated by, or under contract with, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).

Specifically, I request:

Policies, procedures, directives, training materials, or guidance regarding gender-affirming medical or mental health care, including hormone therapy continuation or initiation, housing and classification decisions and medical accommodations for transgender detainees.

Communications (including emails, memoranda, letters, meeting notes) between ICE, the Department of Homeland Security, ICE contractors, state agencies or local government entities regarding:

The provision or limitation of gender-affirming care for transgender detainees;

Compliance with state laws restricting public funding or provision of transgender-related medical treatment, including but not limited to Kansas Senate Bill 63 (“Help Not Harm Act”).

Contracts, intergovernmental service agreements (IGSAs), statements of work, task orders or amendments between ICE and any state, county or private detention facility addressing medical care responsibilities, standards of care or exclusions applicable to transgender detainees.

Grievances, complaints, incident reports, investigations or internal reviews relating to alleged denial, delay, modification or termination of gender-affirming medical care for transgender ICE detainees.

Billing records, invoices, reimbursements or denials reflecting whether gender-affirming medical services were approved, denied or excluded from payment.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

JasmineLewin

title: Transgender Healthcare for ICE Detainees in Contracted Jail Facilities

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Transgender Healthcare for ICE Detainees in Contracted Jail Facilities
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

For the period of January 1, 2023, until whenever this request is fulfilled, I request access to and copies of the following records concerning the provision of medical and mental health care to transgender individuals housed in your facility under contracts or agreements with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). Specifically:

1. Policies, procedures, protocols or training materials regarding gender-affirming medical or mental healthcare, hormone therapy continuation or initiation, housing, classification or medical accommodations for transgender detainees.
2. Communications (including emails, letters, meeting notes) between your agency and ICE or ICE contractors, the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, or any county/state officials regarding compliance with Kansas Senate Bill 63 (“Help Not Harm Act”) or any limits on government funding or provision of transgender-related medical treatment.
3. Contracts, intergovernmental agreements, statements of work, or amendments between your agency and ICE that address medical care responsibilities and standards applicable to transgender detainees.
4. Grievances, complaints, incident reports, or internal reviews relating to alleged denial, delay, or modification of transgender-related medical care for ICE detainees.
5. Invoices, billing records, or reimbursement documentation showing whether gender-affirming care was approved, denied, or excluded from payment.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

JasmineLewin

title: Surprise AZ Planning & Zoning, ICE Warehouse

communications.communication:
To the Public Records/FOIA Officer:
Under the Arizona Public Records Act, I am requesting an opportunity to obtain copies of public records relating to the property located at 13290 W Sweetwater Ave, Surprise, AZ 85379.
Specifically, I am requesting the following records created, submitted, or received between January 1, 2025 and the date this request is processed:

- All building permits, renovation permits, variance requests, or "Change of Use" applications filed for the aforementioned property.
- All code compliance inspection reports, certificates of occupancy, and violation notices regarding the property.
- Any site plans, architectural drawings, or engineering evaluations submitted by the property owner, their LLC, or the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) regarding retrofitting the facility.

To expedite this request and reduce the administrative burden on your office, I am requesting these records in their native electronic format (e.g., PDF for documents, .PST or .EML for emails) delivered via email or secure download link.

If any part of this request is denied or redacted, please provide a written response citing the specific statutory exemption being applied.

If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me beforehand if the estimated cost will exceed $25. However, I also request a waiver of all fees, as the disclosure of this information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of local government operations and infrastructure planning.

Thank you for your prompt assistance and public service.

Sincerely,
Matthew Ruehle

title: Obama Presidential Library: Convergence of Mifsud, Epstein, Andreyev and Timoshenkova at SPIEF 2015

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records regarding the intersection of specific individuals and entities at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum (SPIEF) in June 2015. 

I. Records Requested

I request all records, including cables, meeting logs, attendee rosters, security manifests, photographic evidence, open-source video collection or dissemination or internal briefing summaries, that discuss or list the following individuals as participants, attendees, or delegates at SPIEF 2015:

Joseph Mifsud (linked to the Russian International Affairs Council).

Jeffrey Epstein (specifically seeking verification of his travel to St. Petersburg during the forum window).

Anton Andreyev (representing Vdolg.ru or the Roscongress Foundation).

Daria Timoshenkova (aka Daria Aslanova, representing Vdolg.ru or Roscongress).

II. Specific Inquiry

I am seeking to determine if these four individuals were present at the same forum events, specifically within the "Young Leaders Forum," the "Fintech/IT Innovation" pavilions, or the plenary sessions organized by the Roscongress Foundation.

III. Keyword Search Parameters

To facilitate a comprehensive search of electronic records, cables, photo archives and internal databases, I request that the following keywords be used:

Entities: "Vdolg.ru", "Vdolg", "Вдолг", "Roscongress", "SPIEF 2015", "Young Leaders Forum", "P2P lending Russia".

Individuals (Phonetic/Aliases): "Mifsud", "Jeffrey Epstein", "Andreyev, Anton", "Andreev, Anton", "Timoshenkova, Darya", "Timoshenkova, Daria", "Aslanova, Daria", "Aslanova, Darya", "Дарья Асланова."

Technical/Operational: "INN 7714808861", "Project Lakhta", "Information Operations St. Petersburg", "Identity Harvesting", "Digital Sovereignty Forum".

III. Targeted Offices

Please search the records of the National Security Council (NSC), the Office of the National Security Advisor, and any "Spot Reports" or cables shared by the U.S. Embassy in Moscow (specifically the Political-Economic and Regional Security sections).

Note: Of special interest is the possible convergence of Epstein, Mifsud, Andreyev and Timoshenkova in one event. 

Andreyev and Timoshenkova were pioneers in Russian FinTech and used their expertise to create the financial infrastructure that assisted the Kremlin's 2016 election interference efforts. The Epstein files includes several documents which detail Epstein's interest in attending the networking event and hobnobbing with young Russians in the financial sector. Here is an example: https://www.justice.gov/epstein/files/DataSet%209/EFTA01191262.pdf

Plain language: If Epstein was at this event, documentation of it by the U.S. government would have likely been generated. 

Thank you to the Obama Presidential Library and for the library's commitment to transparency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: Flock Accounts

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Flock Accounts
communications.communication:
To the FOIA Officer of Lincolnwood Police Department,

This request is made under the provisions of Illinois Freedom of Information Act. for the following records:

Records identifying all individuals who have had user access to the department’s Flock Safety system.

This request covers the entire period from the department’s initial adoption of Flock through the date this request is processed.

Please include all available information for each user, including:
• First and last name
• Email address
• Phone number
• Job title or position
• Role or permissions within the system
• Identity provider
• Date of last login
• Whether access was enabled or disabled for functions such as User Management, Search, Device Management, Hotlist Tool, etc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the case of any applicable fees, it is requested that an estimate of the total charges be provided prior to fulfilling this request. The preferred method of receipt is through electronic delivery.

Your assistance and cooperation in this matter are greatly appreciated. A response within 5 business days, as the statute requires, is anticipated.

With thanks,

David S. (he/him/his), Lucy Parsons Labs

title: Leila Shahid

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Leila Shahid
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Palestinian diplomat Leila Shahid (13 July 1949 – 18 February 2026). Her name is spelled ليلى شهيد in Arabic. Her death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find her France24 obituary at the following link: https://www.france24.com/en/video/20260219-leila-shahid-first-female-palestinian-ambassador-dies-in-france-at-76

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an associate editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Domestic Terror Lists

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Domestic Terror Lists
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is a FOIA request. Another DHS Agent has claimed that he will place someone on the “Domestic Terrorist App.”
Please provide:

1) Records that describe the content and purpose of the following lists or databases:  Bluekey, Grapevine, Hummingbird, Reaper, Sandcastle, Sienna, Slipstream, and Sparta (including the HEL-A and HEL-C reports generated by Sparta).
2) Records that describe where the data and names list reside.
3) Records that describe who has authority over the names on the list.
4) Records that describe what legislation was used to authorize the initiation of these lists.
5) Records that describe who authorized the initiation of these lists.

Please search ALL AGENCY RECORDS, located in the entire universe of records of DHS including Homeland Security Information Network (HSIN), Intelligence Records Systems (IIRS), Terrorist Screening Database (TSDB), Treasury Enforcement Communications System, Investigative Case Management (ICM) system or any other filing system equivalent to the FBI’s Sentinel, EGuardian, Guardian, Prohibited Access, Restricted Access, National Crime Information Center, Central Records Systems, and/or any other record filing system within your agency containing records. It is NOT acceptable for you to only search in a subset of all agency files as it may not contain the records that the agency has.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Winter Calvert

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is a FOIA request.  Another ICE Agent has claimed that he will place someone on the “Domestic Terrorist App.”
Please provide records that have detail on this application.  In particular,

1)  Records that describe Who or what company wrote the application?
2)  Records that describe What organization distributes the application?
3)  Records that describe Where the data and names list reside?
4)  Records that describe Who has authority over the names on the list?
5)  Records that describe What contract number was used to create this application?

Please search ALL AGENCY RECORDS, located in the entire universe of records of DHS including Homeland Security Information Network (HSIN), Intelligence Records Systems (IIRS), Terrorist Screening Database (TSDB), Treasury Enforcement Communications System, Investigative Case Management (ICM) system or any other filing system equivalent to the FBI’s Sentinel, EGuardian, Guardian, Prohibited Access, Restricted Access, National Crime Information Center, Central Records Systems, and/or any other record filing system within your agency containing records. It is NOT acceptable for you to only search in a subset of all agency files as it may not contain the records that the agency has.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Winter Calvert

title: Waitlists for programing in MA prisons

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Waitlists for programing in MA prisons
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Most recently available DOC data on the number of inmates on waitlists and number of inmates enrolled for Academic Education Programs, Vocational Education Programs, and Technology Education Programs within Massachusetts state prisons.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Luke Wise

title: Public Records Request – Data Dictionary and Code Definitions for Previously Produced Records

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Public Records Request – Data Dictionary and Code Definitions for Previously Produced Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am submitting this request for records necessary to accurately interpret and analyze data previously provided in response to our prior request regarding individuals incarcerated for or convicted of drug-free zone law violations.

Specifically, I am requesting:
A complete data dictionary, codebook, schema documentation, or similar record that defines and explains all data fields, column headers, abbreviations, acronyms, numeric codes, and categorical values contained in the dataset(s) or report(s) previously produced. I've attached a copy of the documents sent to our team to provide context on the fields and abbreviations in question. 


Documentation explaining, for each field included in the prior production:


The full field name and plain-language definition


All possible values and their meanings


Coding schemas (including numeric, alphanumeric, or system-generated codes)


Offense codes and any statutory crosswalks used


Facility type classifications and related codes


Custody status classifications


Sentence type classifications


Parole eligibility and release date fields


Demographic coding conventions (including race, ethnicity, gender, age-related fields, etc.)


Any internal terminology, shorthand, abbreviations, or system labels appearing in the records


Any record layout guides, database schema descriptions, report-generation manuals, internal guidance documents, or technical documentation used by staff to generate or interpret the responsive reports.


This request is limited to documentation explaining the structure, fields, and codes used in the previously produced records. I am not requesting additional individual-level case data beyond what has already been provided. 

If any portion of this request is maintained by another division, unit, contractor, or agency, please forward the request as appropriate or advise me of the correct custodian.

If there are fees associated with fulfilling this request, please notify me in advance if the total cost will exceed $100. I respectfully request a waiver of fees, as this request is made on behalf of a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, the information is sought in the public interest, and it is not being requested for commercial purposes.

I request that the records be provided electronically in their native format (such as PDF, Excel, CSV, or other standard electronic format). If this is not feasible, please advise of the available formats.

If any portion of this request is denied, please cite the specific statutory exemption(s) relied upon and provide information regarding the applicable appeal procedures.

If clarification would assist in processing this request, I welcome the opportunity to discuss it. Thank you for your time and anticipated cooperation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with Angel Carter.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Funeral Home records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list (spreadsheet, database export, or equivalent record) of funeral providers that were offered entry into, enrolled in, graduated from, withdrew from, or were expelled from the Funeral Rule Offenders Program (FROP) between 1/1/2018 and the date on which this request is processed, including for each provider:
  – business name and any DBA
  – city and state
  – date offered, date enrolled, and final status/disposition date
  – disposition status (current / graduated / withdrawn / expelled)
  – category of Funeral Rule issue(s) implicated (high-level description is sufficient)

To minimize any privacy or confidentiality concerns, I do not request consumer complainant identities, personal contact information for individuals, or any financial worksheets showing providers’ gross sales. If any portion is exempt, please redact only the exempt material and release the remainder.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Akash Mehta

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P066761-021826
communications.communication:
Dear Michael Michael: 
Our office received your open records request pursuant to Missouri's Sunshine Law, Chapter 610, RSMo. Your request has been assigned number P066761-021826. The Patrol is committed to adhering to the Sunshine Law and to ensuring that the public obtains access to open records that are not otherwise closed by law. The Sunshine Law requires each public agency to adhere to certain standards. This letter is designed to ensure that you understand our process for fulfilling your records request. Three Business Day Notice Requirement: 
The requested records are not immediately available for dissemination or inspection. The Patrol is required to notify you that additional research time will be required to fulfill the request. This correspondence satisfies the Sunshine Law's notice requirement within the required three business day period. Section 610.023.3, RSMo. 
 Additional Research Time is Required: 
The Patrol receives thousands of open records requests each month. Our Patrol Records Division personnel are dedicated to meeting the intent of Missouri's Sunshine Law and strive to respond to each request in a timely manner. The Patrol operates in all 114 Missouri counties and the independent city of St. Louis. Accordingly, many records maintained by the agency are not centrally located within, or immediately accessible to, the Patrol's Custodian of Records in Jefferson City. Our staff must research your request and ensure that we have captured all responsive records  ̶  regardless of their location within the agency. The research process is time-consuming, but we will make every effort to expedite your request. Estimated Time for Completion: 
The majority of our requests are fulfilled within thirty business days. Some requests require additional research time due to their scope or complexity. Our team will conduct an initial review of your request. If we estimate that the request will be fulfilled within thirty business days, we will not send an updated time estimate. However, if we estimate that the request will take longer than thirty business days, we will provide an updated time estimate that provides a detailed justification for the additional research time. Billing: 
As it relates to billing, Missouri law allows the Patrol to charge fees for copies and research time. Specifically, "[r]esearch time required for fulfilling records requests may be charged at the actual cost of research time." Section 610.026, RSMo. The Missouri Supreme Court recently determined that "staff time is the time required to provide access to public records maintained on computer facilities, recording tapes or disks, videotapes or films, pictures, maps, slides, graphics, illustrations or similar audio or visual items". Gross v. Parson, 624 S.W.3d 877, 884-89 (Mo. 2021) (internal quotations omitted). 
The Patrol will never bill you for redaction time or any research time conducted by our legal staff. You will only be charged for copies and staff research time as permitted by Missouri law. Please let us know if you have questions related to the billing estimate. 
Our team will forward a bill estimate to your attention once we have calculated the permissible costs and fees. The Patrol will not provide the responsive records until receipt of payment. Section 610.026.2, RSMo. 
We appreciate your patience as we review, research, and fulfill your open records request. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. If you wish to withdraw or clarify your request, or if you have questions, please call our office at (573) 526-6146, or (573) 526-6167. 
 
Sincerely, 
Gerard G. Callahan 
Custodian of Records 
 
Login Link: https://mshp.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/Login.aspx

title: 1996 Study on VMI going Private

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: 1996 Study on VMI going Private
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The current superintendent and other members of the VMI administration recently made public statements regarding the controversy over VMI potentially going private, in which they referenced a 1996 formal study on that potential action, which they subsequently claim the VMI Board of Visitors voted against. title: DOJ Voter Data Request Communications (Secretary of State, Records Management)

communications.subject: Vermont Public Records Act Request: DOJ Voter Data Request Communications (Secretary of State, Records Management)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Vermont Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

From January 20, 2025 to the present:

1. All correspondence, emails, letters, and written communications between the agency and the U.S. Department of Justice, including but not limited to the Civil Rights Division, the Office of the Attorney General, and the Executive Office for Immigration Review, relating to voter registration data, voter files, voter rolls, or voter list maintenance.

2. All internal communications within the agency (including emails, memoranda, and briefing materials) discussing, referencing, or responsive to any DOJ request for voter registration data or any proposed or executed memorandum of understanding with the DOJ regarding voter data.

3. Any lists, spreadsheets, databases, or other records received from the DOJ identifying specific voters for removal, investigation, or further review.

4. All records relating to the engagement of any third-party contractor in connection with DOJ voter data requests or voter list maintenance activities conducted pursuant to any agreement with the DOJ.

If any records are withheld in whole or in part, please identify the specific statutory exemption relied upon for each withholding.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Audrey Nielsen

communications.subject: Re: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: DOJ Voter Data Request Communications (District Of Columbia Board Of Elections)
communications.communication:
​Ms. Nielsen:


I am writing to acknowledge the receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated February 19, 2026.  In accordance with D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c), I will either make the documents you have requested, or a legally segregable portion thereof, available to you, or notify you of my determination not to make the requested documents available, on or before Thursday, March 12, 2026, which is the 15th business day after the date upon which I received your request.


While FOIA requests may be made submitted by mail, fax, or email, please note that FOIA requests submitted online through the DC FOIA portal<https://myfoiadc.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/(S(siyfpx1ughr034w0udncodaq))/supporthome.aspx> will be easier to track and process.


Should you require any additional information prior to the receipt of my response, please do not hesitate to contact me.


Sincerely,

Terri Stroud

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: DOJ Voter Data Request Communications (New York Board of Elections)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

From January 20, 2025 to the present:

1. All correspondence, emails, letters, and written communications between the agency and the U.S. Department of Justice, including but not limited to the Civil Rights Division, the Office of the Attorney General, and the Executive Office for Immigration Review, relating to voter registration data, voter files, voter rolls, or voter list maintenance.

2. All internal communications within the agency (including emails, memoranda, and briefing materials) discussing, referencing, or responsive to any DOJ request for voter registration data or any proposed or executed memorandum of understanding with the DOJ regarding voter data.

3. Any lists, spreadsheets, databases, or other records received from the DOJ identifying specific voters for removal, investigation, or further review.

4. All records relating to the engagement of any third-party contractor in connection with DOJ voter data requests or voter list maintenance activities conducted pursuant to any agreement with the DOJ.

If any records are withheld in whole or in part, please identify the specific statutory exemption relied upon for each withholding.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Audrey Nielsen
